content.title: Portfolio Rebalancing Strategy for Conservative Investor
bullets: Current equity allocation is at 50%, which exceeds the recommended range for a conservative risk profile.
Recommended equity allocation is between 25% and 40%, with a target of 32.5%.
Action required: Reduce equity exposure by approximately 17.5% of the total portfolio.
paragraphs: As a conservative investor, it's crucial to align your portfolio with your risk tolerance. Currently, your equity exposure is significantly higher than recommended. To mitigate risk and stabilize returns, a reduction in equity holdings is necessary. This can be achieved by reallocating funds from high-risk equity categories to more stable debt instruments.

To effectively reduce your equity exposure, consider booking profits in small and mid-cap equities and shifting these funds into short-duration debt funds or corporate bond funds. These categories offer lower volatility and more predictable returns, aligning well with a conservative strategy.
For liquidity and near-term financial needs, liquid funds are a suitable option. They provide easy access to your money while offering modest returns.

Diversification is key to managing risk. Allocating 5-10% of your portfolio to international equities through US/global index funds can provide exposure to global markets and reduce domestic market dependency. Additionally, investing 5-10% in gold via sovereign gold bonds or gold ETFs can act as a hedge against inflation and currency fluctuations.
actions: Reduce equity allocation by 17.5% by selling small and mid-cap equities.
Reallocate 10% of the portfolio to short-duration debt funds.
Allocate 5% to corporate bond funds for stable returns.
Consider placing 5% in liquid funds for immediate liquidity needs.
Introduce 5-10% of international equity exposure through global index funds.
Invest 5-10% in gold via sovereign gold bonds or gold ETFs for diversification.
